JournalInfo.JournalTitle: International Journal of Multimedia Information Retrieval

IssueInfo.IssueTitle: Special Issue: Concept Detection with Big Data

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Distributed cross-media multiple binary subspace learning

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Information Science and Electronic Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Due to the ubiquitous existence of large-scale data in today’s real-world applications, including learning on cross-media data, we propose a semi-supervised learning method, named Multiple Binary Subspace Regression, for cross-media data concept detection. In order to mine the common features among the data with multiple modalities, we project the original cross-media data onto the same subspace-level representation simultaneously by mapping to the corresponding subspaces for dimensionality reduction. All the subspaces are set to be binary, which only involve the addition operations and omit the multiplication operations in the subsequent computation owing to the good property of the binary values. The dimensionality reduction to a binary subspace and the concept detection on this subspace are also optimized simultaneously leading to a semi-supervised model. For dealing with large-scale data, our learning method is easily implemented to run in a MapReduce-based Hadoop system. Empirical studies demonstrate its competitive performance on convergence, efficiency, and scalability in comparison with the state-of-the-art literature.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In many real-world applications, one data instance usually has different representations. This is especially true for cross-media data. By cross-media data, it is meant that data exist in different modalities from multiple sources such that knowledge discovery must be done simultaneously and synergistically across these different modalities [35]. Cross-media concept detection is the application to detect the concept of the cross-media data. For example, an instance can be described by different types of features, such as image features, text features, and audio features. How to effectively make use of the cross-media features has received intensive attention in the literature.

Though individual feature modalities might be sufficient on their own for a given learning task, they can often provide complementary information to each other resulting in an improved performance on the learning task in many cross-media applications. Thus, it is a challenging problem to discover the consistent information hidden in the different modalities. Such consistent information not only contains the sharing concepts among all the modalities, but also involves the differences for the discriminative nature of the different modalities. Most of the existing algorithms [7, 23] ignore such information and adopt originally provided features for the classifier design leading to a suboptimal solution.

With the rapid development and popular use of Internet and other digital resources, the volume of the data keeps growing in a quite fast speed. Given the fact that today’s data are generally of a huge size, a distributed algorithm is of great importance in accelerating the learning speed on a large-scale cross-media dataset. Conventional parallel regression models [13, 21, 28] give their design of parallel implementations regardless of accelerating the learning feature procedure, whereas our approach explicitly takes this into consideration.

Based on the above observations, we propose a multiple binary subspace regression (MBSR) algorithm that deals with the large-scale cross-media concept detection problem. Note that directly conducting a learning approach on the original data space is generally intractable due to the high-dimensional characteristics and may lose the common information shared by the different modalities; we accomplish a joint subspace mapping and learn a concept detection model simultaneously as shown in Fig. 1, which is different from the traditional modality-independent training methods and has a better training speed. To further speed up the training and testing procedures, we accelerate our model by adding a binary constraint on the feature mapping function. Since the binary data only include zeros and ones, multiplications become simple additions. This fact simplifies the subsequent computations and is quite attractive in a large-scale problem solving. Moreover, due to the fact that the unlabeled data are easier to obtain than the labeled data in the real world, especially in the applications with large-scale data, MBSR is designed as a semi-supervised model that utilizes the labeled data and the unlabeled data simultaneously. Due to the large-scale data computation, we design a way to apply the learning model to a MapReduce-based Hadoop system.
Fig. 1
Workflow of MBSR. Cross-media features (e.g., text and image features) are jointly mapped into a binary consistent subspace by an accelerated mapping function to explore the more effective representations. Based on the representations in the subspace, a semi-supervised learning model is introduced for concept detection

In summary, our main contributions are as follows:
A semi-supervised learning method, named MBSR, is proposed for high-dimensional data concept detection, which achieves the dimensionality reduction to a binary subspace and the concept detection on the subspace simultaneously.
MBSR is designed as a semi-supervised learning algorithm, which makes use of the labeled data and unlabeled data for training and thus exploits the latent information of the unlabeled data to enhance the concept detection performance.
An original dataset is projected to a binary subspace. Due to the binary property, the computation complexity is substantially reduced, which is of great importance in the model learning with large-scale data.
For dealing with large-scale data, MBSR is easily fit into a parallel framework. It is implemented to run in a popular MapReduce-based Hadoop system.

Section1.Heading: Related work
Section1.Para: The cross-media or multimodal information retrieval and classification are the popular applications in recent years [16, 24, 25, 35]. For such applications, concept detection [30] plays a key role to result in reasonable solutions. Recent literature such as [26, 31] shows that linear regression is successfully used in the applications of data fitting and concept detection. For capturing the concepts of the high-dimensional data, subspace methods are proposed recently. Yuan et al. [34] present a fast part-based subspace selection algorithm, called the binary sparse nonnegative matrix factorization, which makes full use of the sparseness property. Hua et al. [15] propose a semi-supervised concept factorization, called discriminative concept factorization, instead of the nonnegative matrix factorization technique for data representation. They accomplish a linear regression task on the result of factorization.

Conventional algorithms work well on relatively small datasets that can be stored in the memory. However, such sequential algorithms are very slow due to the frequent disk access and are easy to exceed the disk space. Therefore, scalable approaches (e.g., [10, 11]) are introduced to solve the large-scale concept detection problem. Meanwhile, optimization methods are proposed for parallel computing such as stochastic gradient descent, coordinate descent, and distributed least square method.

Stochastic gradient descent method decomposes the original problem into many smaller problems and utilizes the gradient descent method on stochastically selected smaller problems. Zinkevich et al. present a novel data-parallel, stochastic gradient descent algorithm in which the training data are accessed locally and only the model is communicated at the very end [37]. Bottou applies the second-order stochastic gradient and averaged stochastic gradient to solve large-scale learning problems [1]. Gemulla et al. [12] solve the distributed matrix factorization problem also based on stochastic gradient descent method.

Coordinate descent is another popular parallel strategy in the literature. Coordinate descent generally changes the original problem to many one-variable subproblems while fixing the other variables. Chang et al. [5] propose a novel coordinate descent algorithm for training a linear SVM with the
$$\ell _2$$
ℓ 2
loss function. Hsieh et al. [14] propose a novel dual coordinate descent method for a linear SVM with
$$\ell _1$$
ℓ 1
and
$$\ell _2$$
ℓ 2
loss functions. Yu et al. [33] give the feature-wise coordinate descent solution for distributed NMF.

Bagging strategy [3] is a parallel approach utilized for distributed problems recently. Studies have applied the bagging approach to a distributed system [4, 37]. The bagging approach has an advantage of fitting for the implementation to distributed computing techniques such as MapReduce. Recently, [2] considers the alternating direction method of the multiplier method for distributed learning. Yu et al. [32] propose a block minimization framework for primal and dual SVMs. Mateos et al. [21] distribute sparse linear regression by quadratic programming or coordinate descent. Shalev-Shwartz and Tewari [28] describe and analyze two stochastic methods for
$$\ell _1$$
ℓ 1
regularized loss minimization problems, such as the Lasso [22].

In addition, our subspace learning approach is different from the low-rank representation [18]. The work of Liu et al. [18] corresponds to the dimensionality reduction component that factorizes the data matrix into two lower-rank matrices. Liu et al. [18] aim to achieve sparse solutions while our approach aims to a binary solution for parallelization. Besides, our approach focuses on proposing a distributed regression approach to predicting the concept of the cross-media data samples. This paper is a concept detection application extension of the work [36] in three aspects: (i) the goal of this paper is to train a concept detection model by making use of the cross-media features and then to predict the concept of new data samples. (ii) we introduce the parallel implementation details on the MapReduce-based Hadoop framework in Sect. 3.3 in this paper. (iii) extensive experiments are conducted and reported in this paper.

the loss function. However, to directly achieve a regression model with the original cross-media features is intractable due to the high-dimensional property. In general, the original features should be mapped to subspace-level representations. Considering that the different modalities share some common relations and reveal some other different latent information, it is reasonable to map all the features with different modalities to the same subspace-level representation. This mapping strategy leads to two advantages. One is to discover the sharing relation in all the features. The other is to decrease the complexity of computing the regression. Thus, the optimized problem becomes 2
$$\begin{aligned} \min _{\beta }{\frac{1}{m}\sum _{i=1}^{m}{L(\beta ;w_i,y_i)}+Map(w_i,\{a^{(p)}_i\})+\Omega (\beta )}, \end{aligned}$$

Section2.Heading: Evaluation
Section2.Para:
Given the fact that the coefficient matrix
$$\beta $$
β
fits the low-dimensional vectors in the binary subspace, we face the problem of how to map the samples of the test dataset to the subspace. Our approach utilizes induction strategy instead of transduction strategy for acceleration reasons (refer to [6] to see the analysis).

The MBSR algorithm is organized in Algorithm 1.

Section2.Heading: Parallel implementation
Section2.Para: We implement MBSR on MapReduce-based Hadoop framework. As one of the parallel processing frameworks, MapReduce [8, 9] decomposes a computing problem into several pairs of Map and Reduce tasks and computes these pairs in parallel. Since the updating rules of MBSR are easily designed in a blockwise parallel manner, the capacity of the MapReduce framework can be fully exploited for parallelization.

Section3.Heading: Partition strategy
Section3.Para:
Due to the large-scale and high-dimension properties, matrices
$$Y$$
Y
,
$$A^{(p)}$$
A
( p )
,
$$W$$

, and
$$H^{(p)}$$

( p )
are all huge matrices. For the sake of dealing with them in the MapReduce environment, these matrices need to be partitioned into small blocks. The blocks are then assigned to different computers for distributed computing. In general, two ways of partitions exist. One is to partition
$$W$$
W
,
$$H^{(p)}$$
H
( p )

$$Y$$

along the shorter dimensions, and to partition the original matrix
$$A^{(p)}$$

$$W$$
W
and
$$H^{(p)}$$

( p )
along the longer dimensions. As mentioned in [17], we take the former strategy since it can better reduce the communication cost among computers. We use symbol
$$W_{(i)}$$

$$A^{(p)}_{(i,j)}$$

$$W$$

In general, given a matrix, the ordering of rows or columns does not influence the expression of the original data; thus, permuting the rows or columns is allowed. This idea is known as row–column exchangeability [29]. Based on this property of matrices, a matrix can be partitioned based on the strategies such as bagging directly, random partition, and the partition based on a special structure. For a convenient operation consideration, the first two strategies of the partition are widely used in real-world applications, especially for a Hadoop framework.

Section3.Heading: Parallelization strategy
Section3.Para: After partitioning the matrices into blocks, we discuss how to design the updating rules of MBSR for a MapReduce environment. We give these updating rules as Eqs. (4), (5), and (6).

Note that three types of operations are easily completed in parallel.
The element-wise product (Hadamard product), element-wise division, and element-wise addition can be done in block-wise. Thus, these operations can be designed for a parallel computation in the way that blocks of matrices are assigned to different mappers according to their indices.
The multiplication of the small size matrix
$$\beta $$
β
and a huge matrix
$$N$$
N
can be designed in parallel in the way that different blocks of
$$N$$
N
are assigned to different mappers and
$$\beta $$
β
is assigned to all the mappers.
The multiplication of the selection matrix
$$S$$
S
and another matrix
$$N$$
N
is easily computed due to the fact that it only involves the summation of the elements in
$$N$$
N
.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para: In this section, we report the experimental results of our approach with four competing algorithms on two cross-media datasets.

Section3.Heading: Datasets
Section3.Para:
In order to evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm, two popular cross-media datasets are used: NUS-WIDE and Wikipedia. The first dataset, NUS-WIDE,
http://lms.comp.nus.edu.sg/research/NUS-WIDE.htm
. contains 269,648 images and the associated tags from Flickr, with a total number of 5018 unique tags and 81 concepts. For the feature representation, we use the tags as the text feature vectors and the images are represented as color histograms of 512 dimensions (8
$$\times $$
×
8
$$\times $$
×
8 dimensions for RGB channels). The second dataset, Wikipedia feature articles,
http://www.svcl.ucsd.edu/projects/crossmodal/
. consists of 2866 images, each with a short paragraph describing the image. The images are labeled with exactly one of the 10 different semantic concepts, such as art and geography.

Section3.Heading: Parameter settings and competing algorithms
Section3.Para:
The intermediate variables (
$$W$$
W
,
$$\{H^{(p)}\}_{p=1,2,\ldots }$$
{
H
( p )
}
p = 1 , 2 , …
, and
$$\beta $$
β
) are initialized from the interval
$$(0, 1)$$
( 0 , 1 )
at random.
$$\{\lambda ^{(p)}\}_{p=1,2,\ldots }$$
{
λ
( p )
}
p = 1 , 2 , …
,
$$\{c_p\}_{p=1,2,\ldots }$$
{
c p
}
p = 1 , 2 , …
, and
$$\mu $$
μ
are all set as 0.5 for the initialization. The constant
$$s$$
s
for updating
$$\lambda ^{(p)}$$
λ
( p )
is given as 5 and the threshold
$$thre$$
t h r e
is given as 0.01 in all the experiments. The subspace dimension
$$k$$
k
is set as 50 by default and the setting of
$$k$$
k
is analyzed in Sect. 4.2.1. Both datasets are divided into three parts with the same size: the first part is taken as the labeled training data; the second part as the unlabeled training data; and the third part as the testing data.

The Hadoop cluster is equipped with 9 nodes (1 master node and 8 slave nodes), each of which has two Intel Xeon E5606 processors with four 2.13 GHz cores and 8 GB RAM. The Hadoop cluster is configured to allow at most two mappers and two reducers on each node. In the experiments, 16 mappers and 16 reducers are used for the parallelization. The factorized data matrix is typically split into
$$160\times 160$$
160 × 160
blocks, and each mapper is associated with
$$10\times 10$$
10 × 10
blocks.

We implement four parallel regression methods for a comparison study, namely SCD [28], D-Lasso [21], LLR [13], and DR.
SCD describes a stochastic gradient descent method for
$$\ell _1$$
ℓ 1
regularized loss minimization problems.
D-Lasso distributes sparse linear regression by quadratic programming or coordinate descent.
LLR is a Bayesian logistic regression approach that uses a Laplace prior to avoid overfitting and producing sparse solutions.
DR is implemented as a decomposition method by two steps: applying the distributed NMF [17] for dimensionality reduction and then using the Ridge regression on the lower-dimensional data for the concept detection.

Section3.Heading: Model evaluation
Section3.Para:
Initialization stability analysis Since MBSR leads to a local optimum, it is necessary to evaluate whether the testing accuracy is sensitive to an initialization. For each dataset, we conduct 10 experiments with different random initializations to check its stability. Table 1 reports all the accuracy values in ten different runs. The running times with different initializations are not reported here, because an initialization strategy only changes the values in the matrix and it does not affect the computation complexity. The experimental results indicate that MBSR is not sensitive to the initialization, although it does not achieve a global solution.

Sparsity analysis We define the sparsity of a matrix as the percentage of the non-zero elements. Here we focus on the sparsity of the subspace matrix
$$H$$
H
. Figure 5 shows the sparsity with different settings of
$$k$$
k
. Overall, the results indicate that matrix
$$H$$
H
is always sparse enough. The sparsity goes low with the increasing value of
$$k$$
k
. Although it is not awfully sparse when
$$k$$
k
is small, the computation involving
$$H$$
H
is also not costly due to its binary property.
Fig. 5
Sparsity analysis on two datasets. The results indicate that matrix
$$H$$

is truly sparse consistently

Setting the parameter
$$k$$
k
We examine the model variation with different settings of
$$k$$
k
. Figure 6a gives the accuracy results and Fig. 6b gives the time cost results on different settings of
$$k$$
k
. The results indicate that the time cost approximately has a linear relationship with the value of
$$k$$
k
. However, the testing accuracy increases slower and slower with the increasing value of
$$k$$
k
although the accuracy increases monotonically with the increase of
$$k$$
k
. Considering the balance between the accuracy and the learning speed, we choose
$$k=50$$
k = 50
as a reasonable setting in the rest of the reported experiments.
Fig. 6
The model variation with different settings of
$$k$$
k
. Considering the balance between the accuracy and the learning speed, we choose
$$k=50$$
k = 50
as a reasonable setting

Section3.Heading: Experiments on general size datasets
Section3.Para:
Concept detection performance Table 2 shows the concept detection results of the five algorithms in the accuracy metric on the two datasets. It is observed from Table 2 that MBSR achieves a higher accuracy than the competing algorithms consistently. To investigate how the unlabeled data affect the performance by varying the number of the unlabeled data points, we have actually conducted a series of experiments with different numbers of the unlabeled data points on the NUS-WIDE dataset. The results show that increasing the amount of the unlabeled training data may improve the accuracy moderately to a certain degree by sacrificing the running speed. For example, training with half of the unlabeled data results in about 0.02
$$\%$$
%
reduction of accuracy, about 15 % time acceleration, and almost the same speed improvement of the multi-processor environment over the one-processor environment.
Table 2
The concept detection results of different algorithms in accuracy on the two datasets
Metric
Dataset
MBSR
SCD
D-Lasso
LLR
DR
Accuracy
NUS-WIDE
0.237
0.196
0.185
0.193
0.173
Wikipedia
0.312
0.295
0.282
0.246
0.212
Clearly, MBSR achieves the best concept detection performances consistently Bold values indicate the best results

Convergence speed Figure 7 reports the convergence speeds of the different methods. The accuracy in the Y axis represents the testing accuracy value at each iteration. Note that all the five methods have different objective functions, making it unreasonable to compare the difference in function loss. Therefore, we use the accuracy instead of the objective function loss to show the convergence speed. Figure 7a shows the result on the NUS-WIDE data, which indicates that MBSR has a noticeable improvement over the other four methods. Besides this, the curve of MBSR appears smoother than those of the other methods, indicating that MBSR is more stable. Note that DR obtains the worst accuracy and the lowest convergence speed. The curve of DR does not start from time 0 due to the fact that DR costs some time to accomplish the dimensionality reduction. SCD, D-Lasso, and LLR have a similar convergence performance except that SCD converges a little faster and LLR achieves a better accuracy. However, MBSR converges to the best local minimum and has the fastest convergence rate of all the methods. Figure 7b shows a similar result on the Wikipedia dataset.
Fig. 7
Convergence analysis on NUS-WIDE and Wikipedia datasets. MBSR converges to the best local minimum and has the fastest convergence rate of all the methods

Efficiency Having presented the results on the convergence, we turn the focus on another important factor efficiency. The efficiency here is defined as a parallel algorithm’s performance with respect to the number of the mappers. We examine this factor to verify whether a model works well in a large-scale distributed system. Figure 8 reports the running speed improvement of the five methods with the increasing number of the mappers on NUS-WIDE and Wikipedia data, respectively. The speedup means the relative speed improvement of the multi-mapper environment over the one-mapper environment. The upper bound is along the diagonal, which goes linearly with the increase of the number of the mappers. A higher slope means that a model suits better for a large-scale, distributed system. The results indicate that MBSR achieves the best speedup performance of all the methods. The reason why the practical speedup cannot achieve the theoretical upper bound is mainly due to the communication cost among various machines. However, as the number of the mappers increases, the speedup increases monotonically with the increasing number of the mappers, which indicates that the communication cost does not dominate the main cost of an algorithm.
Fig. 8
Speedup analysis on NUS-WIDE and Wikipedia datasets. Apparently, MBSR achieves the best speedup performance of all the methods

Section3.Heading: Scalability analysis
Section3.Para:
To investigate the scalability of MBSR, we conduct concept detection experiments on two large-scale synthetic datasets, referred to here as NUS-WIDE+ and Wikipedia+, respectively, generated by scaling up the two real datasets using random oversampling and perturbation. To do this, we create new feature vectors by randomly selecting existing feature vectors and then adding exponential noise with a mean value 0.1. This process is run repeatedly until the datasets are scaled up to 10 million instances. Table 3 documents the time costs of different methods when in convergence. Unfortunately, when an experiment is conducted on the very large datasets, SCD and D-Lasso always report memory crash. Therefore, only the results of LLR and DR are reported here for the comparison. From Table 3, we see that MBSR is more computationally efficient than the two competing algorithms.
Table 3
Runtime performances of different methods on the large-scale synthetic datasets with 10 million data instances
Metric
Dataset
MBSR
LLR
DR
Time cost (in min)
NUS-WIDE+
682
795
906
Wikipedia+
486
724
782
Clearly, the computational efficiency of MBSR is higher than those of the competing algorithms Bold values indicate the best results

We further examine how time cost goes with the number of the instances to show whether MBSR can truly deal with large datasets or not. To obtain different sizes of data, we randomly sample instances with a replacement from the original dataset. Figure 9 reports the scalability study by showing the convergence speed on different subsets of NUS-WIDE and Wikipedia datasets, respectively. We note that MBSR has a noticeably clear improvement over LLR and DR on the scalability for both datasets, as the convergence speed gap between MBSR and the other two methods increases when the dataset size also increases. Clearly, LLR and DR have higher time complexity than MBSR, which shows that adding the binary constraint can accelerate the computation speed. In principle, the binary subspace learning is capable of taking less disk space and computer memory leading to reducing the computation complexity.
Fig. 9
Scalability analysis of different algorithms with the increase of the instance number. Clearly, MBSR has a lower computational cost than the competing algorithms consistently

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: We have developed a distributed, semi-supervised algorithm, called Multiple Binary Subspace Regression (MBSR), that scales up well for very large-scale data. It is designed for large-scale, cross-media data concept detection. Given the fact that data in many cross-media learning problems are large scale in nature, MBSR serves well as an effective and efficient core to the solutions. Theoretical and empirical studies in comparison with the existing literature demonstrate MBSR’s competitive performance on the effectiveness, convergence, efficiency, and scalability.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgments
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work is supported in part by the National Basic Research Program of China (2012CB316400) and Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Center on Media Data Cloud Processing and Analysis. Z. Zhang is also supported by US NSF (CCF-1017828).
